thread.title: Premier Investments profit rises 20.7% to $88.1 mln
thread.title_full: Premier Investments profit rises 20.7% to $88.1 mln

author: Sue Mitchell
title: Premier Investments profit rises 20.7% to $88.1 mln
text:
Premier opened almost two dozen Smiggle stores last year, taking the total store footprint to 188, and has unveiled plans to open 40 each year in the UK, including stores in Scotland and Wales. Photo: Adam McLean
Sales at Solomon Lew's Premier Investments are set to crack the $1 billion mark this year and net profits will exceed $100 million for the first time as the retailer presses ahead with aggressive global expansion plans for its fast-growing Smiggle stationery brand.
Premier opened almost two dozen Smiggle stores last year, taking the total store footprint to 188, and has unveiled plans to open 40 each year in the UK, including stores in Scotland and Wales.
Smiggle is also moving into Malaysia and Hong Kong for the first time this year, after successfully testing the brand in Singapore over the last two years, and sees scope for 50 stores within five years.
Premier Investments chairman Solomon Lew (R) and CEO Mark McInnes at the company's national distribution centre at Truganina. Photo: Vince Caligiuri
"Smiggle will be a significant profit driver to the group over the next five years with potential for 200 stores (in the UK) and sales in excess of $200 million," Mr Lew said on Friday after reporting Premier's full year results.
Advertisement "Smiggle is delivering on its potential as a truly unique global brand," said Premier Retail chief executive Mark McInnes.
"Led by John Cheston, our managing director for Smiggle, we achieved a seamless and rapid roll-out across multiple markets and did so profitably. We remain confident in the size of the future opportunity available to Smiggle and our management capability to achieve it."
Peter Alexander sleepwear delivered double-digit growth in sales.
Strong sales and margin growth at Smiggle and sleepwear brand Peter Alexander underpinned a 20.7 per cent increase in net profit to $88.1 million for the 12 months ending July - slightly below market consensus forecasts around $90 million.
Group sales rose 6.2 per cent to $961.9 million, as double-digit growth at Smiggle and Peter Alexander and solid gains at casual clothing chain Jay Jays offset subdued growth at Just Jeans and womens wear brands, Dotti, Portmans and Jacqui E.
Comparable store sales rose 3.4 per cent across the group in the July-half, an improvement on the 1.1 per cent growth in the first half, taking full year same-store growth to 2.2 per cent.
Online sales rose 31 per cent, fuelled by strong gains at Dotti, Portmans, Smiggle and Peter Alexander, and are expected to reach 10 per cent of total sales over time.
Earnings before interest and tax jumped 13.9 per cent to $105.7 million, exceeding forecasts around $102 million. Premier also booked a $12.8 million profit from its 27 per cent stake in appliance maker Breville.
Gross margins rose a weaker than expected 103 points to 63.1 per cent, swelled by lower clothing tariffs, reduced discounting and more direct sourcing from overseas.
However, costs of doing business rose sharply as Premier opened 16 Smiggle stores in the UK.
"The company had good second half sales momentum, but gross margin expansion was constrained by (the weaker Australian dollar) and rising costs," said Citigroup analyst Craig Woolford.
Premier increased its final dividend from 20¢ to 21¢, taking the full year payout, including a special dividend in the first half, to to 51¢.
Mr Lew said the group, which is sitting on $282 million cash and a $200 million pool of franking credits, would consider further capital management initiatives in future.
Mr Lew and Mr McInnes issued no profit guidance, but analysts are forecasting net profits to grow 15 per cent in 2016 to $101 million, fuelled by strong sales growth at Smiggle.
The company is expecting cost savings of more than $2 million a year over three years from its new national distribution centre in Truganina in Melbourne, with all seven brands now operating from the DC.
Mr McInnes said the new DC had the scale, capacity and technology to support Premier's growth aspirations across all sales channels.
